Parish Year Date Buried Parish Buried Total Location Notes
1663 Amsterdam, Holland The plague arrives in Holland, but its origins are unknown. Italy, Turkey, Cyprus, and Crete are suspected points of origin.
1663 Rotterdam, Holland
1664 End of November-Beginning of December Long Acre, Upper End of Drury-Lane 2 Frenchmen die.
1664 Last Week of December Long Acre, Upper End of Drury-Lane Another man dies in the same house.
1665 February 12 H.F. notes that a man died in a different house, but in the same parish and also of the plague.
St. Brides 1664 December 20-27 0 Both St. Brides and St. James Clarkenwell are adjacent to St. Andrews Holborn. H.F. notes that the usual number for burials per week in St. Giles and St. Andrews was roughly 12 to 17 or 19 (3). He also notes the usual number of burials per week in St. Brides and St. James were roughly 4 to 6 or 8 (5) .
St. James Clarkenwell 1664 December 20-27 8
1664 December 20-27 291 H.F. notes that the usual number of total burials per week was between 240 and 300 (6). It is not clear what parishes are included in these numbers.

St. Giles's 1665 April 18-25 30 8 die from spotted fever, which H.F. notes was often considered the same as the plague.
1665 April 26-May 2 388 4 die from spotted fever.
St. Mary-Wool-Church 1665 May 1-8 Bearbinder-lane, near the Stocks-market This parish is within the walls of the City. The Frenchmen who died of the plague had previously lived in Long Acre near infected houses and did not know he, himself, was infected.
St. Andrew's-Holborn 1665 May 1-8 6 total die from spotted fever.
St. Clement's-Danes 1665 May 1-8

1665 May 9-16 343
St. Giles's 1665 May 17-22 40
1665 May 17-22 385 The official record says that 14 died of plague and 14 of spotted fever. H.F. suspects that the total number of deaths from the plague is closer to 50.
St. Giles's 1665 May 23-30 53 The official records says that 9 died of plague, which was revised to 29 when 20 cases of spotted fever were later determined to be plague.
1665 May 23-30
1665 June 1-8 H.F. provides no numbers, but reports that the plague was beginning to spread more quickly. Causes of death are typically listed as "Feaver, Spotted-Feaver, and Teeth."
St. Giles's 1665 June 9-16 120 H.F. suspects the actual number of dead from the plague is closer to 100.
The City (97 Parishes) 1665 June 9-16 Wood-street H.F. notes that these are the first deaths in the City. The plague has not reached Southwerk yet however.
The City (97 Parishes) 1665 June 9-16 Fenchurch-street The bills of mortality are about 700 a week in the parishes around H.F.'s home just prior to his leaving.
The City (97 Parishes) 1665 June 9-16 Crooked-lane
Southwark 1665 June 9-16
1665 Mid-July 1268
The City (97 Parishes) 1665 Mid-July
Southwark, incl. Lambeth 1665 Mid-July
St. Giles in the Fields 1665 July 4-11 H.F. notes that the plague spreads through the parishes of Clerkenwell, Cripplegate, Shoreditch, and Bishopgate on its way to Aldgate, Whitechapel, and Stepney. The plagues begins to abate in the west end as it enters the east end.
St. Martins in the Fields 1665 July 4-11
Aldgate 1665 July 4-11 H.F. refers to these parishes as the Tower-Hamlets, which had time to prepare for the plague by shutting up houses. The result were fewer deaths than surrounding parishes that same time period, such as St. Len. Shoreditch, St. But. Bishopsg. and St. Giles Crippl., which had far more deaths.
Whitechapel 1665 July 4-11
Stepney 1665 July 4-11

1665 July 25 550 H.F. cites this weekly number for roughly the end of July.
1665 4000 It is not clear what the time frame is for this number. Perhaps the height of the plague, whenever that is.
London and Suburbs 1665 Aug. 8 - 15 5319 59,870 H.F. rounds up the total number of dead from the plague to 50,000 to account for the days missing from the official record. H.F. believes the total number of dead from the plague is not the official 68,590, but closer to 100,000 (96-97).
London and Suburbs 1665 Aug. 15 - 22 5568 59,870 H.F. disputes the Bills of Mortality for the period in Algate, Cripplegate, White-Chappel, and Stepney. They report between 500 and 800 dead a week, but H.F. believes it is closer to 2,000 (96-97).
London and Suburbs 1665 Aug. 22 - 29 7496 59,870
London and Suburbs 1665 Aug. 29 - Sept. 5 8252 59,870
London and Suburbs 1665 Sept. 5 - 12 7690 59,870
London and Suburbs 1665 Sept. 12 - 19 8297 59,870
London and Suburbs 1665 Sept. 19 - 26 6460 59,870
London and Suburbs 1665 Sept. 26 - Oct. 3 5720 59,870
London and Suburbs 1665 Oct. 3 - 10 5068 59,870
1665 H.F. speculates that between 1500 and 1700 people died a day from the plague during its height.
Algate 1665 Beginning of Sept. 1000 H.F. speculates that the parish buried over a 1000 a week for two weeks.
White Chapel 1665 Beginning of Sept. 600 H.F. speculates that the number was twice the 600 that was officially recorded.
1664 December Long-Acre, Drury-Lane H.F. places the origin of the plague here, on the West Side, and observes that the plague then traveled gradually and slowly toward the City.
The Town 1665 February - May H.F. cites the previously noted 17 deaths at the end of May to underscore how slow the progression was. It is not until they reach 3000 deaths a week that Southwerk, Wapping, Ratclif and Redriff became concerned.
St. Giles's in the Fields 1665 August 8 - 15 242* 4030* H.F. compares St. Giles and Cripplegate against the other three parishes to suggest a tilt toward the latter during this period, while the overall numbers are going up as the plague spreads.
Cripplegate 1665 August 8 - 15 886* 4030*
Stepney 1665 August 8 - 15 197* 4030* These numbers are largely from the part of Stepney that is adjacent to Shoreditch (Spittle-fields) and not that part which is next to Lime-House, Ratcliff-high-way, and St. Katherine's, where the numbers were far lower.
St. Mag. Bermondsey 1665 August 8 - 15 24* 4030*
Rotherhith 1665 August 8 - 15 3* 4030*
St. Giles's in the Fields 1665 August 15 - 22 175* 5319* H.F. observes that people in Stepney Parish, which includes Lime-House, Redcliff, Wapping, and Ratcliff, felt relatively safe from the worst of the plague, so they didn't take necessary precautions, like leaving.
Cripplegate 1665 August 15 - 22 847* 5319*
Stepney 1665 August 15 - 22 273* 5319*
St. Mag. Bermondsey 1665 August 15 - 22 36* 5319*
Rotherhith 1665 August 15 - 22 2* 5319*
Norwood, Camberwell, Dullege, Lusum 1665 Sept. and Oct. H.F. notes that many infected people wandered into Surrey, which is more woody and open. As a result, no one there would aid the poor and distressed out of fear of infection.

St. Giles's, Westminister 1665 H.F. locates the origin of the plague here.
St. Giles in the Fields, St. Andrew's Holborn, St. Clement-Danes, St. Martins in the Fields, Westminster 1665 Middle of July H.F. notes that this was when the plague was at its height in this part of London.
Cripplegate, St. Sepulchers, St. Ja. Clarkenwell, St. Brides, Aldersgate End of July H.F. notes that, as the plague began to abate in the western part of the city, it moved east into these parishes.
The City (97 Parishes), Southwark (All Parishes), Stepney, White-Chapel, Aldgate, Wapping, Ratcliff End of July H.F. notes that, at the same time, these parishes were barely affected by the plague.
St. Giles Cripplegate 1665 July 25 - August 1 554 1889

The City (97 Parishes), Southwark (All Parishes) 1665 Beginning of September Eastern Suburbs H.F. notes that, as the plague abated in the West and North-West parishes, it began to rage in this part of London.
St. Giles's Cripplegate 1665 September 12 - 19 456 6060 H.F. offers the following Bills of Mortality as evidence of the plague's movement and how, as it abated in one part of London, it grew worse in another.

St. Giles's Cripplegate 1665 September 19 - 26 277 4900 H.F. disputes the official numbers, which but the total number of burials at about 8,000-9,000. He believes the number is closer to 10,000-12,000 (183).

The City (97 Parishes) 1665 - July 1 H.F. refers here to the entire period of the plague up to this date.
Liberties 1665 - July 1
Southwark (8 Parishes) 1665 - July 1
Stepney, Aldgate, White-Chappel 1665 - July 1
1665 2nd to Last Week of September 8297 H.F. notes that this was the highest Bill of Mortality during the plague, just prior to the following week when the numbers went down.
1665 Last Week of September 6460 H.F. speculates that the number of total deaths declined by nearly 2000, marking the beginning of the end of the plague.
1665 First Week of October 5720
1665 Dr. Heath predicts that no fewer than 60,000 were infected; 20, 477 died while 40,000 recovered. If things had continued as before, 50,000 of that number would have died while 50,000 more would have become infected. The source of these numbers is not clear.
1665 Another Week of October 2665 It is not clear if this is the next week. An 1,849 decrease from 5,720 does not equal 2,665, but 3,421.
1665 Next Week of October (1000-1800) H.F. notes that, while people were still dying of the plague, the numbers were getting lower and people were returning to London.
1665 First Week of November H.F. believes that the increase is the result of people returning prematurely to London. The Physicians report that there were 3,000 new infections, but the source of this number is not clear.
1665 November 905
1665 December H.F. notes that the winter weather helped the plague abate, yet the numbers still increased in some placed.
1665 First Three Weeks of September H.F. notes that some believe 20,000 died a week during this period, while others dispute that number. H.F. states his preference for the official numbers of 7,000-8,000 a week.
1665 To the End of the Year H.F. notes that there were still deaths from the plague to the end of 1665.
1665 First Week of October? H.F. notes the decrease for the first week, but does not state the month. I assume October since the number echoes those previously mentioned.
1665 Last Three Weeks (30,000) H.F. quotes a friends calculation's. He also posits 100,000 who had become infected. The date is not clear, but I assume he means the three week prior to the first decrease in the Weekly Bills.
